children.value: course authors, instructors, and teaching assistants
to help you quickly get started with writing and previewing content in this project.

spanning multiple disciplines including physics, chemistry, and computer science. Each course is managed as an independent Jupyter Book using MyST Markdown syntax, and all courses are eventually aggregated on a central portal website (displayed with MkDocs).
No extensive knowledge of web frontend or deployment is required; familiarity with basic Markdown and Jupyter Notebook is sufficient to contribute.
The simplified structure of the overall open-source project is as follows:

knowledge-base/

4. How to Add Chapters / Edit the Table of Contents

children.label: 4. How to Add Chapters / Edit the Table of Contents

children.value: 4.1 Steps to Add a New Chapter

children.label: 4.1 Steps to Add a New Chapter

children.value: Create a new file under the
Draft your content in the new file:

# Chapter 5: Spin and Statistics

Main content goes here...
and add your new chapter to the ToC list in the

project:
toc:
   - file: intro.md
   - title: Quantum Materials Book 1
   children:
      - file: chapters/ch1-wavefunction
      - file: chapters/ch2-operators
      - file: chapters/ch3-schrodinger
      - file: chapters/ch4-angular-momentum
      - file: chapters/ch5-spin-and-statistics   # ‚Üê Newly added
Save and refresh, or rebuild the course as described in the next section.
To change the sequence of chapters, simply reorder the entries in the
file. For example, to move Chapter 5 to Chapter 3, just adjust its position in the list.
5. Local Preview: How to Check Your Work

children.label: 5. Local Preview: How to Check Your Work

children.value: If your course involves substantial interactivity, we recommend authoring with JupyterLab or VS Code with the MyST plugin. For simpler content, editors like Obsidian are suitable. If no interactive code is required, you may submit plain Markdown documents directly.
The recommended MyST v2 fenced directive
may not render well in some editors, so setting up a local environment provides the most accurate authoring experience.
We advise creating a dedicated environment with Conda or venv, and installing
You should then register a custom kernel, e.g. called ‚Äújupyterbook‚Äù, so that interactive code in your files is associated with the correct environment:
: the internal kernel name used in kernelspec references
: the user-friendly name shown in JupyterLab
If you are only responsible for a single course, these tools are all you need. Final Jupyter Book building and deployment can be handled by project maintainers.
(The top-level MkDocs site is generally set up and built by maintainers.)
From your course root directory, for example:
Upon successful build, the following structure is generated:

quantum-mechanics-book/_build/    # Local build outputs (can be ignored)
quantum-mechanics-book/myst.yml   # Book configuration file‚Äîset the title and update ToC as needed
In your course root directory, run:

in your browser and you can view your course as it will appear online.

If you are not familiar with the GitHub workflow, or do not wish to use Git, you may send your course files directly to the project maintainers via email or other file transfer methods for review, editing, and publication.
6.2 Submitting via the Central GitHub Community

children.label: 6.2 Submitting via the Central GitHub Community

children.value: The standard workflow (for contributors comfortable with GitHub) is as follows:
locally to ensure no errors and preview rendering

git status          # View updated files
git add .
git commit -m "Add content for Chapter 3: Schrodinger Equation"
(If using Pull Request workflow) Submit a Pull Request
Open a PR on GitHub and request review/merge by a maintainer
Once merged, maintainers will trigger the build and deployment process (typically automated via GitHub Actions)
Do not directly edit the built artifacts under

; those are static site outputs.
You only need to maintain source files within
Before starting a new course, coordinate with editors and project maintainers to understand the scope and current architecture, and to avoid duplication of efforts.
Each file should focus on a single main topic or chapter to avoid excessively long documents.
It is advisable to include a brief ‚ÄúObjectives / Key Points‚Äù list at the start of each chapter, or a summary at the end.

Strive for clarity and accessibility; aim for a level that allows students to understand current literature. Consider providing both a high-level overview version and a more advanced treatment with derivations or code as appropriate.
Q0: Can I write in languages other than English?

A: Yes, but please coordinate this with the project maintainers beforehand. We encourage contributions in any language, including Chinese. After drafting, we strongly recommend maintaining a parallel English version (as in the
example). Be sure to append language tags (e.g.,
for Chinese content) to all block labels to avoid duplicate label errors during compilation.
Q1: I only know regular Markdown. Do I need to learn MyST?
A: Not necessarily. Most MyST syntax is compatible with standard Markdown, so you can start with basic Markdown and incrementally use MyST features for formulas and code blocks as needed.
Q2: Do I need to create my own
A: Project maintainers typically provide an initial template. Your main responsibility is to maintain the chapters list under the
, and make minor adjustments such as the title or authors as needed.
Q3: Why can‚Äôt I see the main portal (homepage) locally?
A: The top-level portal (MkDocs component) is constructed and managed by the maintainers. As a course author, focus on previewing your individual course using MyST-Jupyter Book.
Q4: Do I need to manually create inter-course link URLs?
A: Currently, a fixed URL scheme is used (e.g.,
). Maintainers will provide example paths. You may use these, and any future changes to the scheme will be handled globally.
Q5: Do I need to work on the AI assistant (LLM) front-end or back-end?

A: No. This is a future feature and is still under development. Authors are not required to work on this aspect. The site‚Äôs ‚ÄúAI teaching assistant‚Äù is powered by core front-end components and back-end API; your focus should be on clear, well-structured content to maximize the assistant‚Äôs effectiveness.
First contact a project maintainer to discuss potential contributions and review existing sample content together.
Once you‚Äôve decided on the scope, locate your assigned course directory under
and draft a course introduction; establish a general structure.
to reflect your envisioned chapter structure.
, or adapt the template, and try drafting a short sample section.

cd courses/quantum-mechanics-book
myst init
myst start --execute
If all looks good, expand the content as needed, and submit your work following the process outlined above.

For any questions, please reach out to a project maintainer or open an issue in the repository.
We encourage you to contribute your course content to this open knowledge base to benefit more students üôå
